questions.text: A 5-year-old child posted for circumcision has to be given a caudal epidural block for analgesia. The anaesthetist palpates the sacral hiatus for the same, which is formed by non-fusion of:
questions.solution:
• The spine is composed of vertebral bones and intervertebral discs. There are 7 cervical, 12 thoracic and 5 lumbar vertebrae. The sacrum is a fusion of 5 sacral vertebrae and there are small rudimentary coccygeal
  • Sacral vertebrae normally fuse into one large bone, the sacrum, but each one retains discrete anterior and posterior intervertebral foramina. The lamina of S5 and all or part of S4 normally do not fuse, leaving a caudal opening to the spinal canal, the sacral hiatus.

  • Caudal epidural anesthesia is a common regional technique in paediatric patients. It may also be used for anorectal surgery in adults. The caudal space is the sacral portion of the epidural space. Caudal Anesthesia involves needle or catheter penetration of the sacrococcygeal ligament, covering the sacral hiatus that is created by the unfused S4 and S5 Laminae. The hiatus may be felt as a groove or notch above the coccyx, and between two bony prominences, the sacral cornua.

Key takeaway: Caudal epidural anesthesia is a common regional technique in paediatric patients. It may also be used for anorectal surgery in adults. The caudal space is the sacral portion of the epidural space. Caudal Anesthesia involves needle or catheter penetration of the sacrococcygeal ligament, covering the sacral hiatus that is created by the unfused S4 and S5 Laminae. The hiatus may be felt as a groove or notch above the coccyx, and between two bony prominences, the sacral cornua.

questions.text: The lung volume at the end of a normal exhalation is called functional residual capacity (FRC). FRC is reduced in all of the following scenarios except:
questions.solution:
• The lung volume at the end of a normal exhalation is called functional residual capacity (FRC). At this volume, the inward elastic recoil of the lung approximates the outward elastic recoil of the chest (including resting diaphragmatic tone). Thus, the elastic properties of both chest and lung define the point from which normal breathing takes place. FRC can be measured by nitrogen washout, helium wash-in technique, or body plethysmography. Factors known to alter the FRC include the following:
  • Body habitus: FRC is directly proportional to height. Obesity, however, can markedly decrease FRC (from reduced chest wall compliance and increased abdominal pressure on the diaphragm). Kyphosis can adversely impact both lung volumes and rib mobility.
  • Sex: FRC is reduced by about 10% in females compared with males.
  • Increased intraabdominal pressure: Decreased FRC is associated with laparoscopic procedures, pregnancy, and significant ascites due to increased pressure on the diaphragm from the laparoscopy pneumoperitoneum, the gravid uterus, or from ascitic fluid, respectively. (Option A,B,C)
  • Posture: FRC decreases as a patient is moved from an upright to a supine or prone position. This is the result of reduced chest compliance as the abdominal contents push up against the diaphragm. The greatest change occurs between 0° and 60° of inclination.
  • Lung disease: Decreased compliance of the lung, chest, or both is characteristic of restrictive pulmonary disorders, all of which are associated with a low FRC.
  • Diaphragmatic tone: This normally contributes to FRC, and its contribution is evident with unilateral or bilateral phrenic nerve paralysis.
  • Aging decreases the elasticity of lung tissue, allowing overdistention of alveoli and the collapse of small airways. Residual volume and functional residual capacity increase with aging. Airway collapse increases residual volume and closing capacity. (Option D)

Key takeaway: The lung volume at the end of a normal exhalation is called functional residual capacity (FRC). It decreases with obesity, other conditions that cause an increase in intraabdominal pressure, in supine position, in females kyphoscoliosis, conditions that decrease the lung compliance, diaphragmatic palsy, among others. It increases with ageing and conditions with increased lung compliance.

questions.text: A 30 year old female is posted for an elective caesarean section under spinal anaesthesia. All of the following are absolute contraindications to receive a spinal anaesthesia except:
questions.solution:
Following are the absolute and relative contraindications of spinal anesthesia:


CONTRAINDICATIONS TO NEURAXIAL ANAESTHESIA

  • Major contraindications to neuraxial anesthesia include lack of consent, coagulation abnormalities, severe hypovolemia, elevated intracranial pressure (particularly with an intracranial mass), and infection at the site of injection.(Option B,C,D)
  • Other relative contraindications include severe aortic or mitral stenosis and severe left ventricular outflow obstruction (hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy); however, with close monitoring and control of the anaesthetic level, neuraxial anesthesia can be performed safely in patients with stenotic valvular heart disease, particularly if the extensive dermatomal spread of anesthesia is not required (eg, "saddle" block spinal anesthetics).

Key takeaway: Knowing the absolute contraindications to neuraxial anaesthesia is important to avoid catastrophic complications related to a simple procedure, which can prove detrimental to patients and doctors.

questions.text: What phase is shown by '0' in the given time capnograph trace?
questions.solution:
• Figure shows the representative time capnograph for three breaths.
  • The expiratory segment is divided into phases I, II, III, and IV.
  • The inspiratory segment is referred to as phase 0 in this figure.
  • α denotes the angle between phases II and III, whereas β denotes the angle between phase III and the descending limb of phase 0.
  • Phase IV (dashed line in third breath) denotes the upstroke observed at the end of phase III in some patients.
  • Following is a brief account of the various phases of capnogram:
    • Phase 0 (Inspiration): This phase represents the start of inhalation, where the CO2 level drops quickly to near-zero. Fresh air, which is low in CO2, fills the airway, clearing CO2 from the previous breath.
    • Phase I (Baseline): This is the beginning of exhalation, where the CO2 level remains low and flat. The air at this stage is coming from the conducting airways (anatomical dead space), which contain little or no CO2 because they haven't reached the alveoli where gas exchange occurs.
    • Phase II (Ascending Phase or Rapid Rise): In this phase, exhalation brings CO2-rich air from the alveoli into the airway. The curve rises steeply as the expired air transitions from dead space to alveolar gas, causing a rapid increase in CO2 concentration.
    • Phase III (Alveolar Plateau): This phase represents the alveolar plateau, where CO2 concentration levels off. Here, gas exchange is occurring in the alveoli, so the CO2 level remains relatively constant. The plateau's slope may slightly rise due to uneven ventilation. The peak at the end of this phase is called the end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2), the highest CO2 concentration exhaled and a key measurement in respiratory monitoring.
    • Phase IV (Expiratory Downstroke or Return to Baseline): After reaching EtCO2, the next inspiration begins, causing a rapid drop in CO2 levels as fresh air washes into the airway. This downstroke marks the return to baseline, completing the cycle.

Key takeaway: Inspiratory segment in time capnograph is denoted by '0'

questions.text: During extubation after a cleft lip repair surgery, a pediatric patient developed laryngospasm. Which of the following is the first step in the management of laryngospasm?
questions.solution:
• Laryngospasm is a forceful involuntary spasm of the laryngeal musculature caused by sensory stimulation of the superior laryngeal nerve.
  • Triggering stimuli include pharyngeal secretions or passing an ETT through the larynx during extubation.
  • Laryngospasm is usually prevented by extubating patients either deeply asleep or fully awake, but it can occur-albeit rarely-in an awake patient.
  • Treatment of laryngospasm includes providing gentle positive-pressure ventilation with an anesthesia bag and mask using 100% oxygen or administering intravenous lidocaine (1-1.5 mg/kg).
  • If laryngospasm persists and hypoxia develops, small doses of succinylcholine (0.25-0.5 mg/kg) may be required (perhaps in combination with small doses of propofol or another anesthetic) to relax the laryngeal muscles and allow controlled ventilation. (Option A, B and D)
  • The large negative intrathoracic pressures generated by a struggling patient during laryngospasm can lead to negative-pressure pulmonary edema, particularly in fit, healthy patients.
  • Whereas laryngospasm may result from an abnormally sensitive reflex, aspiration can result from depression of laryngeal reflexes following prolonged intubation and general anesthesia.
  • Bronchospasm is another reflex response to intubation and is most common in asthmatic patients. Bronchospasm can sometimes be a clue to endobronchial intubation.
  • Other pathophysiological effects of intubation include increased intracranial and intraocular pressures.

Key takeaway: The first step in treatment of laryngospasm is to provide gentle positive-pressure ventilation with an anesthesia bag and mask using 100% oxygen or administering intravenous lidocaine (1-1.5 mg/kg).

questions.text: A 30-year-old man had surgery while being intubated. The most effective way to verify the location of the endotracheal tube is:
questions.solution:
The most important and objective indicator of tracheal intubation, however, is the presence of a normal capnogram (carbon dioxide [CO2] waveform) for the presence of at least three breaths. Severe bronchospasm, equipment malfunction, cardiac arrest, or hemodynamic collapse may prevent the appearance of a capnogram tracing despite proper ETT placement.

In patients with adequate tissue perfusion, assess and confirm the location of the endotracheal tube using an end-tidal carbon dioxide detector (such as continuous waveform capnography, colorimetric capnography, or non-waveform capnography). Signs of correct endotracheal intubation:

  1. Detection of ETCO2 by Capnography (Surest confirmation)
  2. Bilaterally auscultated breath sounds
  3. Symmetric chest rise
  4. Absence of epigastric breath sound
  5. Visible mist in the ET tube
  6. Large exhaled Tidal volume
  7. Good compliance of reservoir bag during manual ventilation

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page number:1308, 1309, 1392-1398.

questions.text: Which is the ideal position for Ryle's tube insertion?
questions.solution:
• If the patient is conscious, the best position for inserting the Ryle's tube is sitting with the neck flexed.
  • The best position for comatose individuals is supine with the neck flexed.

The steps for inserting a Ryle's tube include:

  • Position: A conscious patient should be Sitting with neck flexed.
  • Check placement: Ask the patient to speak to assess the tube's position. You can also use pH paper to measure the aspirate pH.
  • Secure: Tape the tube to the patient's cheek to hold it in place.
  • Preparation: Put on gloves, gown, and face shield. Check the nostrils for obstructions and patency. Place a towel over the patient's chest.
  • Anesthesia: Spray a topical anesthetic in the nostril and pharynx at least five minutes before insertion.
  • Lubricate: Apply a water-soluble lubricant to the tip of the tube.
  • Insert: Gently insert the tube into the nose, aiming toward the earlobe.
  • Advance: Ask the patient to take sips of water through a straw while advancing the tube.

It's important to verify the tube's placement before each feeding to prevent complications like aspiration pneumonia.

Confirmation of correct position of Ryle's tube:

  1. Auscultation of epigastrium while injecting bolus of air through it
  2. Chest radiography
  3. pH measurement
  4. Ultrasound

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page number:336.

questions.text: Which of the following does not contraindicate a neuraxial block?
questions.solution:
Patient on antihypertensive medication is not a contraindication for neuraxial block.

Absolute contraindications:

  • Patient's refusal
  • Patient's inability to maintain stillness during the needle puncture (can be seen in case of dementia, psychosis)
  • Raised intracranial tension
  • Severe Hypovolemia
  • Severe stenotic valvular heart disease
  • Marked skin sepsis
  • Marked spinal deformity
  • Marked coagulopathy, blood dyscrasias or full anticoagulant therapy

Relative contraindications:

  • Pre-existing neurological deficit (demyelinating lesions) due to medicolegal problems
  • All severe and marked diseases present in lesser degree (spinal deformity, sepsis)
  • Pre-eclamptic toxemia
  • Mildly impaired coagulation
  • Patients with platelet < 80,000/ml

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page number. 1420,1421

questions.text: A patient is now taking regular drugs for concomitant medical conditions. Which of the following medications can be safely discontinued with a low risk of negative consequences prior to abdominal surgery?
questions.solution:
• All long-term antihypertensive treatment should be continued up to the day of surgery, with the possible exception of angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (ACEIs) and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs).
  • Administration of these medications within 24 hours before surgery is consistently associated with increased risks of intraoperative hypotension, and possibly associated with elevated risks of postoperative myocardial injury. Accordingly, it is reasonable to withhold these medications for 24 hours before surgery.

Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page number:929.
